lexUnit.name: confuse.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: cause to become bewildered or perplexed.

sentence.text: Boswell measured the water journey from Glenelg as twelve miles ; the boatman called it six miles , confusing old logical Johnson with the assertion that a mile on the land equated to two on the sea .
Does it confuse you that I should do the talking and you the listening ?
Or was he merely seeking to confuse people in the West who have been calling for military intervention ?
It would only confuse him to tell him the truth .
He was confusing her , sabotaging the lines of communication between them and making her sound even more guilty than she had to start with .
The comment about the cost confused me ; I was used to thinking of us as being well-off .
You can confuse people even more thoroughly with windows .
` It will confuse them .
Do not confuse yourself .
It was easy , really , getting out of there -- it was just I was confused by it being dark and that .
I 'd asked that he should n't be bottle fed with my expressed milk as it can be more difficult to establish breastfeeding if a baby is confused by a teat .
My senses were confused by this new experience , having previously associated sightseeing with sights to see , not to mention hear and smell .
Also some TV sets are confused by the fudged signal and display pictures which are either too small or unstable .
The modern reader is likely to be particularly confused by Hilton 's discussion of Meditatio , the third great monastic practice .
You were too confused by how the city and the people looked to you .
It has been claimed that interference has disrupted train signals , and electronic equipment from Nintendo Gameboys to video cameras has confused aircraft flight management computers .
Erm , let me try and confuse you first , and then enlighten you later .
Only interviews with the prime suspects could enlighten us now but , instead , they served to confuse still further .
She felt strangely at odds with herself , confused by her own emotions .

The Venetians fortified their main towns -- Naxos Town and Antiparos Town are wonderful examples of this -- creating labyrinths of narrow alleys and cul-de-sacs that were designed to confuse and to demoralize invaders .
